neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message:
Can you change to // ?  There's a py3 incompatibility where using / will result in a float.

>>> type(75 // 2)
<class 'int'>
>>> type(75 / 2)
<class 'float'>

I only know this because we fixed another case recently.
Ops... Good point. I will change it.

I'm wondering if we can re-use throttler here: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/common/utils.py#L90

Its purpose exactly fits this scenario. The idea is that even if you call once function several times very quickly, throttler ensures it'll be called just once in the given time.

Ah cool, I can take a look to see if it's fit.

One thing tho, this ^ is distributed because the last ping value is stored in the OVN database. So, once the "agent list" is handled by a specific API worker and the last ping is set, every other API worker (in any controller) will see it as well.

I wonder if with throttler we can have something like it (I haven't looked at the code yet).

Ok I took a look at it and also talked to Kuba via IRC.

Unfortunately @throttler won't fit here given the distributed scenario. The idea of re-using the "last ping" timestamp stored in the OVN NB DB is so that we avoid periodics in another neutron-server (on other controllers) from pinging it again.

As is, neutron will spawn one health check periodic task per neutron server and we need to coordinate them.

Thanks Kuba, @throttler still pretty useful. I'm sure I will be using it somewhere else soon.
Yes, you're right :) We can't use throttler here, sorry for taking your time.

nit: this is a bit confusing - it reads to me like hey before you upgrade to train make sure you apply this fix, but the fix is part of train, so that's weird. s/have this fix applied before they do/apply a version which includes this fix/

FWIW I thought this was weird when I read it as well, though I didn't put my finger on why.

So what we're really trying to say is:
- If you're upgrading to Train, make sure the Train version you're laying down is one that includes this fix; and
- If you've already upgraded to an earlier Train, you may (or may not) be broken without realizing it, and you should apply the Train with this fix to ensure you are unbroken.

Right?

And I guess the way it's worded currently makes it sound like you can apply this fix independently somehow, which isn't the way people reading a reno in its native habitat will be doing things.

Anyway, I don't have a wonderful suggestion, just thinking aloud.

I'm not sure if it's not clear what I'm trying to say, or you think it won't be clear to other people. I'm trying to address your comment on IRC earlier of making this read like instructions.

If someone is getting ready to upgrade to train, say T.0 and they're reading this and realize their vendor hasn't released T.1 yet, they might want to wait or make sure they're getting the newest packages.

This is also a bit tricky since if you upgraded and got past 399 you can't apply the fix and run the db schema migrations again to resolve the issue, you'd have to do manual DB surgery. So I'd probably either remove this sentence or say if you have already upgraded and are experiencing this issue you will need to manually resolve it by updating existing `instances` table records to set hidden=false.
Users already on Train should upgrade to a version including this fix to ensure the problem is addressed.

No, applying this fix if they're already on T.0 is fine. Their DB won't get fixed up, but the code will handle reading fixed and unfixed instance records. So this is trying to say "don't think this isn't important just because you've already upgraded to T.0"

gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drive.message: Since this is no longer inheriting from HostLink, you don't need the kwargs param and don't need to call the base class initializer.
Agreed. Will remove.

The _segment_to_vlan_encap function is also called from _get_static_ports a couple lines below, which seems redundant. I was thinking you might just pass encap instead of segment to _get_static_ports, but it needs to pass segment to _filter_host_links_by_segment, which uses the segment's physical_network. It seems there are two reasonable options:

1) Don't call _segment_to_vlan_encap here, but just check that the segment is of type vlan instead. Remove the encap param from _update_static_path_for_svi and let it get this from static_port instead.

2) Call _segment_to_vlan_encap here, remove the encap property from the StaticPort class, and pass encap separately wherever needed.

I think the choice depends on whether encap refers to the bound segment's encapsulation, or to the encapsulation presented to the device connected to the switch port. If the former, I think #2 makes more sense, leaving StaticPort focusing on the configuration of the switch port.

The _get_static_ports method calls _filter_host_links_by_segment, which takes a segment. My thinking is that the StaticPort should accept an encap, but the _get_static_ports method should take the parameters needed to create the StaticPort objects (in this case, it needs at least a host and segment, and in the future may take other parameters, sucha as a neutron port). I'll remove this call since it's not needed.
Here we are using the encap param rather than static_port.encap, arguing for option 2 in my comment above.
see above.
Nit: "Should".
Will fix.
Here also we are using the encap param rather than static_port.encap, again arguing for option 2 in my comment above.
see above.

Here we are using static_port.encap, potentially arguing for option 1 in my comment above. But could the different static_ports ever have different encap values, even with the follow-on work for Ironic and trunk ports?
see above.
You removed the kwargs, but not the base class initializer call! This class has no base class.
Thanks!
:-(. Will fix.

I'm still not completely convinced it makes sense to store encap in this class, but not to store segment. If you stored segment, encap could be a property function that returns the encap string based on the stored segment.

Is all this code going to work if the same EPG is bound for different VLAN segments, such as in the case where different dynamic segments are needed on different Ironic hosts?

It's the latter. The segment is used to select an additional interface in the _filter_host_links_by_segment call. It's possible that a single host has multiple interfaces, each on a different physnet; Since the call to _get_static_ports includes a call to _filter_host_links_by_segment, it would handle the case of selecting one of the multiple interfaces, based on the physnet for that segment.

Agreed on the difference between HostLink and StaticPort. I also agree we'd have a different StaticPort for each segment the EPG is bound to. 

What I'm not clear on is whether we'd ever be processing a list of StaticPorts where those StaticPorts involved different (dynamic) segments of the network? 

If so, we'd need to know which segment each StaticPort was for, and storing the segment in the StaticPort would make sense. Then _segment_to_vlan_encap could be replaced with a @property function on StaticPort.

If we only ever process a list of StaticPorts for a single segment at a time, then your current approach of storing just the encap string and passing the segment where needed separately is fine.

OK, after navigating the original code, I see that it is dealing with a single segment for a single host at a time, and it looks like the EPG can have other static paths for other segments and/or other hosts. I'm still not 100% confident of this, but I do now agree the segment probably does not need to be a property of StaticPort.

What I'm still not clear about is why there would ever be multiple StaticPorts for the same host and the same segment. Is this ever expected to happen? Or is the use of a list of StaticPorts/host_links just an artifact of doing the AIM find by host, which could return a list, and then filtering that list by segment?

We could do segment - but the thinking here is that the static port is everything you need to configure the static port in ACI. That in my mind is the difference between a HostLink and the StaticPort. If the same EPG is bound to different VLAN segments, then each of those would have its own StaticPort object.
Won't this raise an exception if remove is True and static_port is None?

To me, this reads like:

  if (not (remove or static_port)) or (not static_port.encap):

So if remove is True, "(remove or static_port)" is True and static_port isn't evaluated. In this case, "(not (remove or static_port))" is False, which means "(not static_port.encap)" needs to be evaluated. So if remove is True and static_port is None, we'll get an exception. 

Or do I have the precedence wrong?
The not applies to the first parenthesized statement. If remove is True, then it doesn't need to check the or condition - the statement is False already, so it just returns.
I need to go back to logic 101. You're right. Will fix.
No need to change it, but plain tuple or a namedtuple might be an appropriate lighter-weight alternative to a class here, since the class does no computation at all.
No, as I said, "no need to change it". But I think namedtuples are good solution for this kind of thing, as there is very little overhead and the members are accessed by name.

I'm going to keep the object for now, since I think it helps readability - sometimes passing around a tuple that has to be parsed in an order jumbles things up, at least for me.  If you feel strongly about this, we can discuss that aspect of it further.

I like the namedtuple idea.  The other optimized class I've seen is when __slots__ is used, with the difference being mutability. Since these objects should be immutable, I think namedtuples are the best choice.

Its still not clear to me if there is any case where there should be multiple static ports for the same EPG/host/segment combination. I'd suggest a REVISIT here and/or in _get_static_ports regarding this. If there can never be more than one, introducing the StaticPort class may not be worthwhile.
will address those.

Actually, if the same host to has multiple NICs wired to leaf switches, could there be multiple host links for that host? If so, I'm not sure anything would/should prevent binding these to the same EPG/network, using the same segment. In that case, I guess there would be multiple static ports returned.

If so, our handling of Ironic static paths should probably be driven by the topology information from the binding:profile, rather than by looking things up by host+segment. That might require a bit more refactoring of this code.
I guess I convinced you that a list makes sense, but it seems some changes related to making it a scalar were not backed out.

I'm going to change this to return just a single static port, as I think that's what the users of this API ultimately need.

The patch for baremetal VNIC types will introduce a kwargs port parameter, which if present will be checked and will use information in the binding:profile. Initially this will only be for baremetal VNIC types, but if we determine that the same parameter can be used for other VNIC types, then we can expand it cover other cases.

I wouldn't have changed this name. This kind of method should not be a public API for other components. I'd prefer to have added a comment indicating it is used by SFC (see similar "# Used by policy driver." comments on methods used by GBP) and maybe a REVISIT that a more appropriate API should be provided. Longer term, I'd prefer we move the code that deals with the mapping to AIM inside the MD, like we did with the L3 plugin.
will do.

I thought we agreed there could be multiple StaticPorts for a host+segment combination when the host has multiple NICs with corresponding host link records in the AIM DB, so this should still say "objects". I would like to keep our task files in the tasks folder. Ansible doesn't have the concept of multiple tasks workflows in a given role, so putting this into a sub directory and including using the relative path is likely going to create confusion in the future, especially as we move toward collections.

I recommend using descriptive naming and prefixing the task files so that their pseudo unique. Something like: 

  tasks/db_information.yml

Given this task file seems to retrieve db information that name would be easily recognizable for future maintainers.

this would default to docker when the var `podman` is undefined. I would recommend setting this like so:

ironic/locking/base.py.message: DHCP

For this and the other tasks, I'd suggest that we make it explicit that it's a node resource that's being locked. We may want to extend the locking interface to support locking other resources in future, such as ports, volumes, or attributes such as the power state of a node.

This could be done in a few ways, such as adding an additional argument that describes the resource to lock, or adding a new set of methods for each resource (is_node_locked etc.), or a separate subobject, a little like the clients (e.g. provider.nodes.is_locked()). The latter could easily allow for a DRY design.

Also, should be task_or_id?

It would only require extra BMC requests if the state is observed to change.

If we want a consistent power state (which I think we do), then we must be holding the (same) lock when querying the power state from the BMC, and updating the node. Otherwise we'll get races, and see 'switch bounce' type behaviour. Of course the sync will always make it correct in the long term, but that could be 2-3 minutes away.

Example: Node starts in power off. t1 is a periodic power sync, t2 is an API call to set the power state to on.

t1: READ power off
t2: API set power on
t2: SET & WAIT power on
t2: LOCK
t2: Update node power on
t2: UNLOCK
t1: LOCK
t1: Update node power off
t1: UNLOCK

So the node ends up briefly on then off again in the DB, but the node is on. The sync will run again eventually and sort this out, but an API observer will see power state transitions that did not happen.
Except that t1 is trying to sync the state to off, and t2 has set it to on, so t1 will see a difference and set it to off.

ironic/locking/base.py.message: ++ Yeah, this all needs to be cleaned up. I started down one path and had to change along the way because of the way some of the conductor code works.

It depends on what the underlying issues are. If it's simply the overhead of acquiring and releasing locks, then a lock manager could help. If there is contention for locks, then the only way to improve matters is to use more fine-grained locking. The classic example is power state update or sync, which can take some time, and cause other requests to 409.

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

ironic/locking/base.py.message: So there is one difference in that the node is refreshed upon the lock and the other lock is not supposed to release until state is achieved... so we should end up in a situation where t2 releases its lock, t1 upgrades task to a lock, the code should check if t1's node now has the desired end state, if so, it can just release the lock and move on.

Yeah I'm not suggesting we do it all in one strike. But if we're adding in a new interface it helps to know what it might be required to do in future.

We need to be careful about late locking - if we didn't have the lock when we queried the power state, then updating the node with that power state could lead to inconsistencies. I guess we could grab the lock if we detect a change, then query the power state again with it held.

In my experience on fujitsu server, it takes just same amount of time as reboot.

I think it doesn't usually take a long time if OS settings is correct.

In case of hand, I believe that most cases are cuased by incorrect OS settings.

Hardware part of NMI action should be work quickly "by design". Probably it takes a long time if OS makes a big memory dumps for example. Looks like Ironic should interact with user's OS, this is not a good idea.

Yuriy,

I got your point when I examined your comment [1].

In case of ipmitool, inject nmi is just a trigger, the ipmitool command execution time is very short, in this sense, the command is async.

However in case of iRMC, I believe other vendor's BMC as well, we can get the OS status via OOB.

So I agree with you that it's not good idea that Ironic interact user's OS directly, but vendor's BMC can query the OS status without interacting user's OS directly.


[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/186700/17/specs/approved/enhance-power-interface-for-soft-reboot-and-nmi.rst  at the line 164.

Best regards,
Naohiro

specs/approved/tooling-for-recorvering-n.message: Please provide examples of how a node can get stuck in an -ING state (and why we can't fix it)

An simple example is when a node in deploying state but the corresponding conductor was broken, then the node get stuck in this state. Any operation to the node will get reject because of it was still reserved by the dead conductor. At the moment, we can either restart the conductor or wait until _check_deploying_states() have an effect. So this spec provide an alternative.

> At the moment, we can either restart the conductor or wait until _check_deploying_states() have an effect

Which is maximum 2 minutes (1 minutes before conductor considered dead, 1 minutes is _check_deploying_status periodic interval). I don't think waiting up to 2 minutes is a huge deal.
I think clear reservation should be optionally and not recommended to user.
how will this tool ensure that a lock is not held on a node?
It will forcibly clear lock if there is one.
But the clear reservation is the key point per my understanding. Otherwise, even if the node is in deployfail state, user can not manipulate it because of the lock.

the actualy alternative is to make sure -ING states don't get stuck. they actually should not - they are not waiting on anything external (unlike -WAIT states). Why can't we figure out where we can get stuck on -ING states?

Per my understanding, the stuck is because of the node is reserved by a dead conductor (the exclusive lock was not released), ironic do have some ways to clear the lock like restart the dead conductor or _check_deploying_states() but people still used to update DB records manually. So let's provide a better choice if they want.
People should do neither really. It's only 2 minutes wait, as IIRC I already wrote
I don't agree with a tool overriding locks, to be honest.

Mark, the single-process model scales neither horizontally nor vertically. This is why I object to even suggesting it here. A lightweight RPC layer can open a way for horizontal scaling by adding more ironic containers while still starting with only one ironic container.

Trying to unpick how and why this enters the picture. Is it because a single process has no way to route requests to the correct conductor, therefore we need RPC to route the client's request directly to the correct conductor?

I'm not sure I follow you here Dmitry. Vertical scaling is easy - add more hardware. For horizontal scaling, container infrastructure typically provides load balancing. Alternatively, if routing to specific conductors is required then client-side routing using something like gRPC is possible.

I'm not necessarily backing either of these approaches, just making the point that scaling is possible.

> Vertical scaling is easy - add more hardware.

specs/approved/container-infrastructure..message:
I'm worried you guys are focusing in too much on scale when my intent with what was written was more usability of ironic as more a swiss-army knife.

In the model I'm thinking, we would only (presumably) receive the request to the process if it could service the request because the caller identified it and addressed it directly. This is actually how our API calls the conductor today.

If we think of the conductor as the swiss-army knife, my hope would be that we would be able to completely step back from our focus on the existing scale model as we are fitting into the different operating/scaling model.

In a swiss-army use case, ironic is more of a tool to be leveraged and not a BMaaS where we would tend to worry about massive scale, concurrency, and lifetime system management.
An alternative would be to separate out a stateful service (as some have talked about doing), for handling things like PXE, consoles, etc. Although that's more services rather than less :)

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

specs/approved/container-infrastructure..message:
I see a couple different models in the container universe:

1) There is only one conductor in one container. It serves all requests.
2) There are multiple conductors from the same container image in the same cluster.

I guess the original thought entry point is that if a requester needs to act upon a specific container and conductor process inside of that container, then it would need to know of it, although under normal circumstances it shouldn't matter.

The result is that any conductor should be able to act upon the requests made, because they would all be operating with the same configuration. This would also mean that for things like iPXE, all conductors would need to create configuration files, but that becomes beneficial in that it is point to single ipxe endpoint kind of action.

nova/compute/api.py.message: could it be possible to filter also by updated_at? which can prevent showing the wrong one in the short window where both instance.hidden=False?

Possibly, I can add a note about investigating that. The problem in this method is I don't really have the context on all of the instances since I'm processing them one at a time. Filtering by updated_at is closer to what I did with duplicate migrations here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/603930/20/nova/compute/api.py@4703

One thing about filtering with updated_at is if the user is explicitly filtering on changes-since/updated_at or sorting on updated_at, we could screw that up if we pick the latest one...so it gets complicated. I'll leave a TODO since it's a more minor issue, but it's why I didn't originally plan on doing the updated_at filtering for instances like I did for migrations. And now that I think about changes-since, the updated_at filtering I'm doing for duplicate migrations could be wrong there as well.

++

I think this is a small understandable race window where user might get two records of the same instance when hidden is False for both. We could use the "updated_at" logic but IMHO its not worth breaking the existing filtering based on changes-since like you said. Besides if operators are that concerned about the accuracy, they can set api.instance_list_per_project_cells to True as a workaround (this could be added to the API documentation in case people freak out when seeing two instances). Its a gamble between perf/accuracy.

To be clear, you'll never see two instances because this _get_unique_filter_method method will only return one, but it could be one you weren't expecting if you hit the window and the exact right time, but as you said that window is extremely small.
I'm kind of surprised to see this here. I would expect to just not have the hidden things in the instance list(s) we pulled...

doc/source/2002.rst.message:
Maybe:

Upcoming change of default behaviour for Neutron API

Maybe:

The neutron-api charm will have a change in default behaviour when deploying OpenStack Ussuri (or newer) with the upcoming 20.05 OpenStack Charms release (May 2020). The value of configuration option ``manage-neutron-plugin-legacy-mode`` will change from 'True' to 'False'.

When 'True' the network management plugin is chosen via the ``neutron-plugin`` option. When 'False' it is chosen through the deployment of a subordinate charm and relating it to the neutron-api application.

The most prominent effect of the change is that you will need to set up a subordinate plugin charm (and possibly associated charms) to get a functional network service. Sample bundles will be updated to enable OVN by default. See `Open Virtual Network (OVN)`_ in the `OpenStack
Charms Deployment Guide`_ for details on OVN.
This change was made within the following upstream context:
Will we need a new ML2/OVS subordinate to support this switchover?

I was thinking to let users just set manage-neutron-plugin-legacy-mode=True to get the existing ML2+OVS(+DVR) functionality for now.

Depending on how much changes upstream do to the existing stuff, a separate subordinate may become a requirement in the future.  We might also choose to do it for completeness, but at this point it time it is not a requirement.
Let's add some upgrade information (in development I understand).
I want to convey here that the migration can be done one application at a time. So I don't want to say remove the relation from all applications at the same time.
let's at least change this to 'relation'

shaker/engine/messaging.py.message:
Would it be sufficient to bind to the IP address from 'server-endpoint' parameter instead of any? 

If the address is wrong then bind would fail, if bind is succeed then agent should be able to reach the server too.

I don't think that will be enough, the problem really comes when running Shaker from a kubernetes pod.Here's an example:
k8 ingress(32.10.12.02)-> K8 haproxy pod-> shaker pod(10.0.0.2)

We can pass 32.10.12.02 as the server_endpoint in the shaker.cfg to the shaker pod. Haproxy then routes all requests from the ingress IP address to Shaker pod IP address and everything works as expected.
 
However if something is wrong with haproxy the routing doesn't happen and the Shaker pod is left in a hung state (and possibly a heat stack that will never be cleaned up is left in Openstack) waiting for a message on the queue that will never come. Since the Shaker pod is now "stuck" the pod will never die and retry either. 

If the haproxy routing goes down mid Shaker run at least we have the agent_loss and agent_join timeouts which will end execution cleanly. 

This is an attempt to as least check things are OK before a run happens in order to not leave everything in a bad state. We can't bind to the 32.10.12.02 ingress IP because the pod Shaker is running in has no idea about this interface.

Got it. 
I didn't take into account that external IP may differ.
